page.title: 04The Quaker Meeting House
page.content: The story of the Quakers dates back to 1864 when John Sargent purchased the Bobbin Mill at the bottom of the village. He was a Quaker but the nearest Quaker meeting house was at Oakerthorpe, so he decided to hold meetings in a cottage at the bottom of Bobbin Mill Hill.Soon other Quakers joined him,including Thomas Davidson who ran the grocer shop and post office on the green, also the local antiquarian.Before long John Sargent and his friends disagreed with the London society of Quakers and in 1869 formed their own society at Fritchley which continued for nearly 100 years. In 1897 the Quakers of Fritchley built a new meeting house on Chapel Street.
